description: From hair +â€Ž pin, 1788 (as hair pin). Adjective sense 1906 in hairpin turn etc.

entries.meaning: A pin or fastener for the hair.
(biology) A kind of ribozyme; hairpin ribozyme.
(chiefly attributive) A very tight bend in a road; a hairpin bend.
examples: The variety of angles in the course, from slow bends to hairpins, will both test your skill as a driver and allow you the opportunity to pass other carts.

entries.meaning: (music) An elongated horizontal v-shaped sign placed underneath a staff to indicate a crescendo or decrescendo.
